abstract: A nonprofit group that lobbies for the removal of the carriage horses from New York City revealed an electric-powered buggy on Thursday.
snippet: A nonprofit group that lobbies for the removal of the carriage horses from New York City revealed an electric-powered buggy on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: The faux-vintage electric car with which horse advocates want to replace Central Park's carriage horses has classic white-wall tires, running boards, mahogany and an "ah-hoogah" horn. On Thursday, in a fourth-floor conference room of Manhattan's Hippodrome -- where circus horses once performed -- Jason Wenig set a model of it across the table from the car's sponsors. Mr. Wenig's company would develop and sell the E.V. at a price from $125,000 to $175,000. Read more »

headline.main: A Tin Lizzy E.V. Unveiled as Central Park Carriage Competitor
